thread.title: Police quiz Aussie tourist in Bali
thread.title_full: Police quiz Aussie tourist in Bali

title: Police quiz Aussie tourist in Bali
text:
THE accommodation site has shot into the headlines for all the wrong reasons with a marketing campaign that backfired, leaving some people quite creeped out. Travel Updates Police quiz Aussie tourist in Bali over stolen motorbike by: Cindy Wockner and Komang Erviani From: Investigation ... police have not yet indicated what charges the Australian might face. Source: AFP 
AN Australian man is in police custody in Bali, accused of trying to steal a motorbike. 
The man, identified by police as James Ian Ramsey, from NSW, is now under interrogation at South Denpasar police station. 
He was nabbed by village security officers no far from the scene of the alleged crime, after the motorbike’s female owner borrowed another bike to give chase to him. 
The alleged crime occurred about 11am on Sunday in a busy street at Sanur. It is not known if the Australian is a tourist or an expatriate living in Bali. 
South Denpasar police chief, Nanang Prihasmoko, said Fisher was still being interrogated and so far had given “random” answers and did not appear focused. Questioned ... the man has been identified by police as James Ian Ramsey. Source: Supplied 
Mr Prihasmoko said that the victim, the bike’s owner, Komang Rusmini, had parked her motorbike in front of a shop where she worked but had forgot to lock it and left the key in the ignition. 
When she was in the shop she heard the sound of her motorbike starting up and raced out to see a foreign man riding away on it, he said. 
“The victim then borrowed her friend’s motorbike to pursue the perpetrator while shouting out asking for help,” Mr Prihasmoko said. 
“At the traffic lights, about 500 metres form the shop, the perpetrator was blocked by a (police assigned to a village as a security advisor) and traditional Balinese guards who were around the 
traffic lights to safeguard a Ngaben (cremation) ceremony,” he said. 
Police have not yet indicated what charges, if any, that the Australian might face, as he is still being questioned and the case is still under investigation. 
Mr Prihasmoko said the Australian Consulate in Bali would be advised of the man’s arrest.
